WRITING.TITLE: *PayPal Hold Question - Please Read/Respond, Thank You*
WRITING.TEXT: Hey guys! Yesterday I was hit with a 21 day hold on a pretty important transaction and I had a few questions about getting the hold reduced/removed. Background: This is my third transaction where I've used PayPal as my payment processor. The first two transactions were close to $1k and this latest one, the payment in question, is a little over $2k. The order is for digital goods and does not have a tracking number. \*The client **DOES NOT** have PayPal so he paid the invoice I sent with his credit/debit card.\* Story: Last evening after my client made the payment, I received the 21 day hold notice. I logged into my PayPal account and saw the held funds with a link that said "Get My Money" under the held amount. I clicked and it brought me to a page where it said I could get my money in 3-7 days if me and the client completed "Order Verification". I clicked on the Order Verification link and it brought me to a page where I could mark my Invoice as Completed, In Progress, or Cancelled. I clicked "Completed" and it redirected me to a page that said something like (paraphrased): "Thanks, we'll be sending this information to your customer, once he verifies the transaction we'll release the funds." Now, here's where the story gets hairy - **my client never received any email from PayPal asking for an order verification.** Perhaps this occurred because he doesn't have a PayPal account? He decided to call PayPal to see what he could do to verify the order via phone, but they told him something very confusing: they said that I, the seller, needed to mark the invoice as "processed" or "services rendered" in order to get the money released. But predictably, when I navigate back to the invoice, I don't have a "Processed" option - I only have "refund" or "archive". I now also have a message at the top of the invoice details that says (verbatim): "You have recently updated your order information. You #8217;ll get your money within 7 days of verification." To me that sounds like the process is incomplete on the customer's end - which he can't complete because he's not a PayPal member and they never emailed him. So now I've very confused - will the funds be available in 7 days or 21 days? Will they hold it indefinitely because the Order Verification can't be completed? Did this somehow get screwed up because the client doesn't have a PayPal account and he just paid the invoice with his credit/debit card? Basically I just want to know when I'm going to get my money, lol. **\*\*\*UPDATED QUESTION: If my client joins up with PayPal, could he verify the transaction after joining up with the same email and payment source he used to make the transaction?\*\*\***

WRITING.TITLE: *PayPal Hold Issue - Please Help!*
WRITING.TEXT: Yesterday PayPal hit me with a 21 day hold on a pretty important transaction and I had a few questions about getting the hold reduced/removed. Background: This is my third transaction where I've used PayPal as my payment processor. The first two transactions were close to $1k and this latest one, the payment in question, is a little over $2k. The order is for digital goods and does not have a tracking number. \*The client **DOES NOT** have PayPal so he paid the invoice I sent with his credit/debit card.\* Story: Last evening after my client made the payment, I received the 21 day hold notice. I logged into my PayPal account and saw the held funds with a link that said "Get My Money" under the held amount. I clicked and it brought me to a page where it said I could get my money in 3-7 days if me and the client completed "Order Verification". I clicked on the Order Verification link and it brought me to a page where I could mark my Invoice as Completed, In Progress, or Cancelled. I clicked "Completed" and it redirected me to a page that said something like (paraphrased): "Thanks, we'll be sending this information to your customer, once he verifies the transaction we'll release the funds." Now, here's where the story gets hairy - **my client never received any email from PayPal asking for an order verification.** Perhaps this occurred because he doesn't have a PayPal account? He decided to call PayPal to see what he could do to verify the order via phone, but they told him something very confusing: they said that I, the seller, needed to mark the invoice as "processed" or "services rendered" in order to get the money released. But predictably, when I navigate back to the invoice, I don't have a "Processed" option - I only have "refund" or "archive". I now also have a message at the top of the invoice details that says (verbatim): "You have recently updated your order information. You #8217;ll get your money within 7 days of verification." To me that sounds like the process is incomplete on the customer's end - which he can't complete because he's not a PayPal member and they never emailed him. So now I've very confused - will the funds be available in 7 days or 21 days? Will they hold it indefinitely because the Order Verification can't be completed? Did this somehow get screwed up because the client doesn't have a PayPal account and he just paid the invoice with his credit/debit card? Basically I just want to know when I'm going to get my money, lol. Any sage advice is most appreciated! :)

As per my original post, there's no tracking number for this transaction, it's a digital good/service... so what you're saying is they hold it indefinitely if there's no tracking? That doesn't make any sense being there's many transactions on PayPal that don't have tracking (payment for services, etc).
Okay, just as long as I didn't screw myself by starting an ordering verification process that can't be finished.
Okay, so I'll just have to wait the 21 days, then? I just want to be sure I didn't get screwed by starting an order verification process that my client can't finish.
INR claims... would that apply to a service or digital goods? I could easily send the email/download link receipts to PayPal as proof of delivery, no?
QUESTION: If my client joins up with PayPal, could he verify the transaction after joining up with the same email and payment source he used to make the transaction?
One More Question: If my client joins up with PayPal, could he then verify the transaction after joining with the same email and payment source he used to make the transaction?
Yes I'm sure he's telling the truth. This is just the first part of an 8 month long project. I've done business with this individual over the course of several years, trust is not an issue.

I've done business with this individual over the course of several years, trust is not an issue. This is the start of an 8 month project with multiple payments due, he's not scamming me. I'm refunding the client's funds and we're going with Google Pay. No fees and he'll just need to verify the transaction with Google Support. I've dealt with them many times and they are consistent. The money will be in my account by tomorrow or Wednesday the latest as long as the refund comes through promptly. After this mess, PayPal can suck it as far as I'm concerned, unless I have an international order and I have no choice.
No worries, thanks for the reply

That's not true, at least at the Walmarts in Florida - they usually keep the TP and PT in the back where people pick up online order and layaway items. They have employees giving out one package of TP and PT per customer.

WRITING.TITLE: Can anyone tell me the name of the track that starts at 44:25?? It's an ambient instrumental genre, 90s, 00s, or 10s.

WRITING.TEXT: Got to jump in here as I'm a relatively recent escapee from New Jersitan. I hailed from Middlesex county. I escaped to Florida and I couldn't be happier. The taxes are lower, the roads are empty after 10pm (I like to drive spiritedly on occasion), and I own four firearms. You can buy as many guns as you want down here - no license or permit required, just the standard fed background check that takes 5 - 60 minutes to process and a 3 day waiting period. No trips to the police station, no fingerprinting, no registration lists, no permits, no fees, no gladhanding/greasing "the right wheels" to get your permit pushed through, no ridiculous 30 day waiting period, no NOTHING. Hell, down here they even sell suppressors and silencers at the Bass Pros, which are kind of like the Walmart of firearm shops. If you go to the specialized gun shops, then you can find some *really* amazing and cool stuff. The gun culture down here is also amazing. I've been at many different ranges and made several friends in the space of a couple months. In fact, that's probably what I enjoy the most about owning a gun - going to the range, practicing, maybe even enter a competition or two, and I get to meet some awesome people along the way. So although I obviously own my guns for home defense, that's not the kind of situation I look forward to, but what I do look forward to is going to the range and having fun. A lot of people who don't own guns just don't understand that there's much more to owning a firearm than home defense. Perhaps a good comparison is taking a self-defense class. You're taking the class so that you can handle yourself in a violent situation, but you're still having fun at the class and making friends, it's about learning new skills and having new experiences. Anyway, I hope you guys come to your senses some day and escape New Jeristan like I did, it's a really freeing feeling. :) PS I do miss NJ pizza, but the out-of-this-world seafood (never had bigger and more tasty shrimp than Gulf shrimp!), the best steaks in the country (Bern's Steakhouse wins best every year), and the to-die-for BBQ that Florida has to offer more than makes up for it.

We have no idea why he needs that service dog. It could be for a physical disability or mental trauma. He may have been in a war and seen some really bad things, etc. If she didn't question his service dog in the first place there would have been no discussion and the guy would have went about his business.
Coming from the son of a divorced family whose father was arrested under false DV accusations and had his business, home, and dignity stripped from him, I find this scene absolutely cathartic.

WRITING.TITLE: FLORIDA - New Car Purchase - Finance Charges are TAXABLE??? Please Help!!
WRITING.TEXT: Hello from the Sunshine State!! :) I just purchased a new car in Mississippi and took it back to my home state of Florida. I paid approximately $61000 for the new car and I had a trade in that was worth $36000. $61000 - $36000 = $24000 sales tax.... right?? WRONG! The woman who called me from the MVC said I owed sales tax on $40000 - how? ***She's including the "finance charge" on the bill of sale,*** ***which is the total interest on the loan, into the sale price of the car.*** I can't find anywhere in Florida law where it says it's legal to be taxed on the INTEREST of a new car loan!! Am I wrong or is the MVC woman wrong? If she's wrong, what do I do from here to correct it? I haven't paid or even gone to the office yet. They called me with this information. \*\*FYI, on the Bill of Sale the sale price of the car and finance charges are listed separately.\*\* Any help would be greatly appreciated, thanks!! :D #8203; \- A Very Frustrated Floridian

WRITING.TITLE: FLORIDA - New Car Purchase, Finance Charges Are TAXABLE??? Please Help!!!
WRITING.TEXT: Hello from the Sunshine State!! :) I just purchased a new car in Mississippi and took it back to my home state of Florida. I paid approximately $61000 for the new car and I had a trade in that was worth $36000. $61000 - $36000 = $24000 sales tax.... right?? WRONG! The woman who called me from the MVC said I owed sales tax on $40000 - how? ***She's including the "finance charge" on the bill of sale,*** ***which is the total interest on the loan, into the sale price of the car.*** I can't find anywhere in Florida law where it says it's legal to be taxed on the INTEREST of a new car loan!! Am I wrong or is the MVC woman wrong? If she's wrong, what do I do from here to correct it? I haven't paid or even gone to the office yet. They called me with this information. \*\*FYI, on the Bill of Sale the sale price of the car and finance charges are listed separately.\*\* Any help would be greatly appreciated, thanks!! :D \- A Very Frustrated Floridian
Thanks for the tip. And yes, the finance charge and the sale price of the car are listed SEPARATELY.

No, no... I paid $61k for the car. That's $2k under the sticker price, which is a very common deal for people to get. It's clearly labeled on the Bill of Sale. If you subtract the trade in value of $36k the total taxable amount comes to: $24k. The total finance charge was about $13.4k, which even if you add that up only comes to $37.4k, so how she comes to "about $40k is eligible for sales tax" (to quote her from our phone conversation) makes no sense to me. She's basically trying to double my sales tax. MVC told me to schedule an appointment and talk with a supervisor about the issue. No one at the facility could give me a yes or no when I asked if they taxed people on the finance charges of their new vehicles. When I said there was nothing in Florida law about taxing finance charges I would usually be greeted with silence and an attempted subject change.

I don't understand how Kelley Blue Book Value comes into play with a new car. A new car has a sticker price. I paid very close to sticker price so there's nothing strange or odd about the sale price. Even if she want to charge me full sticker that would only come to $63420. $63420 - $36000 = $27420 taxable for sales tax. It makes no sense. To answer your query, 7.9%, but my credit is only just barely fair, I'm still rebuilding from a bad decision back in my late 20s. My last car loan was 9.6%.
Kelley Blue on my car new is $64k. Again, this makes no sense. She can't randomly make up a number and decide - "this is how much the car is worth in my opinion."

Thanks, but this is a tax subreddit, I'm doing fine with my finances... but that doesn't mean I'm going allow $1400 to be stolen from me. In 2017, when I bought my other Shelby, I was not taxed on the cumulative interest of my loan. I was taxed on the the SALE PRICE OF THE CAR - TRADE-IN VALUE. That's what the law in Florida states, period. Nothing about finance charges. So why is this happening? Can anyone answer my actual query?
I appreciate the article, but I'm going to need the actual tax law on this, a Car and Driver article isn't going to cut it unfortunately. Does anyone know where to find the statute/law?

Negative, the Blue Book Value for my 2017 Shelby was $36k-$40k, my trade-in value is in the lower end of the spectrum. There's nothing fishy with my trade-in or the price of my car. But for some reason she's nsistent on adding the interest from my loan to the value of the car, which is illegal and nowhere in the tax code. Asking to chat with a supervisor tomorrow, hopefully that happens. Again, she can't use her personal opinion to inflate the value of my car by $14k. BTW, no joke, this woman's name is Karen, and she is starting to live up to her namesake. Screenshot of my car's trade-in value from Blue Book: [Kelley Blue Book Value](https://www.dropbox.com/s/iil5w4kk6zh9x9j/Screenshot%28210%29S.jpg?dl=0)

I never claimed to be a financial savant...In fact, I came to this reddit forum for the specific reason that it's supposedly filled with individuals knowledgeable in tax code/law. There's no reason for her to be adding the interest from the loan to the total of the car sale. That's illegal, and every time I point it out, instead of linking to relevant tax code proving or disproving my query, I'm being tut-tutted for the car deal itself, which is immaterial to the issue. Whether I paid a 2.9% rate or a 15.9% rate, it's illegal to tax me on the interest of the auto loan, the law doesn't change based on your interest rate. Also, if you're unfamiliar with Florida tax code, I'd ask that you refrain from responding. #8203; PS This wouldn't be the first time a motor vehicle employee has screwed/messed with people just because they could.

WRITING.TEXT: I have a different take on this. I honestly have an excellent set of genes. Although before I hit puberty, I basically looked like the white version of Urkel (thick glasses and all), once I hit my teen years I really filled out and now as an adult I'm a decent looking guy. My IQ is very high and I scored so well on my SATs that I was offered scholarships. But I never went to college. My parents divorced and I learned some very harsh lessons about life. (false accusations of domestic violence by my mother, false arrests, destruction of all my childhood pictures and movies out of spite, that sort of thing) This, combined with a childhood rife with school beatings and total rejection, made me a very jaded individual. My life left me with venom in my heart and a very strong feeling that the world simply does not deserve another person like me. There are some very good things I could be doing with my talents, but purely out of spite, I refuse to use them. It breaks my mother's heart and that gives me immense satisfaction. She more than anyone knows my talents and how I'm wasting them. I've refused to use my intellect for anything other than my own self gain, and even that effort is fully concentrated in an industry that is considered debaucherous, meaning my work generates money but absolutely no value to society. It also has the double effect of humiliating my mother - her son is financially successful yet she is still ashamed of him. She can't mention me or what I do to anyone she knows. In fact, many would say that my work is a net negative or even a burden on society, and in all honesty I'm proud to be said burden. In a twisted way, it actually feels good to be considered a stigma by a society that pays me so well. It's one of the few things in my miserable life that gives me a reason to wake up in the morning.

Because it's his show so he decides the format. He doesn't want to remote interview people, he wants to keep it personal. If he's afraid of catching COVID, I say he's a coward. You only live once. Stand up and speak now or put your mask back on and forever hold your peace.

I'm a 6'2" MAN and I wouldn't have defended her either. In fact, I wouldn't defend any woman. Have you ever heard of the feminist movement?? Women are just as independent, strong and powerful as men. The woman in the video should have defended herself against her attacker and kicked his ass. If she allows herself to be treated like that, then that's what she deserves - and before you call me a sexist or a misogynist, if it was a man being treated that way, I would say the same thing. Equal strokes for different folks! ;) I wonder, what makes you think that as a woman you're entitled to impromptu male bodyguards??? Who the fuck are you to decide that you're entitled to male bodies!? Women aren't entitled to use men as their own personal bodyguards, so go fuck yourself, Danielle.
